_**Star Trek: The Next Generation**_ (abbreviated as _**TNG**_ and
_**ST:TNG**_) is an American [science-fiction television
series](/wiki/Science_fiction_on_television "Science fiction on television")
in the _[Star Trek](/wiki/Star_Trek "Star Trek")_ franchise created by [Gene
Roddenberry](/wiki/Gene_Roddenberry "Gene Roddenberry") that ran from 1987 to
1994. Roddenberry, [Maurice Hurley](/wiki/Maurice_Hurley "Maurice Hurley"),
[Rick Berman](/wiki/Rick_Berman "Rick Berman"), [Michael
Piller](/wiki/Michael_Piller "Michael Piller"), and [Jeri
Taylor](/wiki/Jeri_Taylor "Jeri Taylor") served as executive producers at
different times throughout its production.

The show was very popular, reaching almost 12 million viewers in its 5th
season, and the season seven finale in 1994 was watched by over 30 million
viewers.[4][5] The show spawned two reasonably popular spin-offs set in the
same sci-fi universe time and place, and 4 theater films with the cast of the
show. In the early 2000s the show Enterprise, although more oriented towards
re-booting the series was also in the same fictional universe, but an earlier
time.

The series involves a [starship](/wiki/Starship "Starship") named _Enterprise_
and is set in the nearby regions of the [Milky Way galaxy](/wiki/Milky_Way
"Milky Way"), the [Alpha Quadrant](/wiki/Alpha_Quadrant "Alpha Quadrant"). The
first episode takes place in the year 2364, 99 years after the start of the
five-year mission described in the original series, which began in 2265.

It features a new cast and a new [starship
_Enterprise_](/wiki/Starship_Enterprise "Starship Enterprise"), the [fifth to
bear the name](/wiki/USS_Enterprise_\(NCC-1701-D\) "USS Enterprise
\(NCC-1701-D\)") within the franchise's storyline. An introductory statement,
delivered by [Patrick Stewart](/wiki/Patrick_Stewart "Patrick Stewart") and
featured at the beginning of each episode's title sequence, stated the
starship's purpose in language similar to the opening statement of _[The
Original Series](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Original_Series "Star Trek: The Original
Series")_ , but was updated to reflect an ongoing mission, and to be gender-
neutral:[6]

> Space: the final frontier. These are the voyages of the starship
> _Enterprise_. Its continuing mission: to explore strange new worlds, to seek
> out new life and new civilizations, to boldly go where no one has gone
> before.

_TNG_ premiered the week of September 28, 1987, drawing 27 million viewers,[7]
with the two-hour pilot "[Encounter at Farpoint](/wiki/Encounter_at_Farpoint
"Encounter at Farpoint")". In total, 176 episodes were made (including several
two-parters), ending with the two-hour finale "[All Good
Things...](/wiki/All_Good_Things..._\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "All
Good Things... \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" the week of May 23, 1994.

The series (1987–94) was broadcast in [first-run syndication](/wiki/First-
run_syndication "First-run syndication") with dates and times varying among
individual television stations. Further _Star Trek_ spin-offs followed _The
Next Generation_ : _[Star Trek: Deep Space
Nine](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Deep_Space_Nine "Star Trek: Deep Space Nine")_
(1993–99), _[Star Trek: Voyager](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Voyager "Star Trek:
Voyager")_ (1995–2001), _[Star Trek: Enterprise](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Enterprise
"Star Trek: Enterprise")_ (2001–2005), and _[Star Trek:
Discovery](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Discovery "Star Trek: Discovery")_ (2017–present).
The series formed the basis for the seventh through the tenth of the [_Star
Trek_ films](/wiki/Star_Trek_\(film_series\) "Star Trek \(film series\)"), and
is also the setting of numerous novels, comic books, and video games.

In its seventh season, _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ became the first and
only syndicated television series to be nominated for a [Primetime Emmy Award
for Outstanding Drama
Series](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Drama_Series "Primetime
Emmy Award for Outstanding Drama Series"). The series received a number of
accolades, including 19 Emmy Awards, two [Hugo Awards](/wiki/Hugo_Award "Hugo
Award"), five [Saturn Awards](/wiki/Saturn_Award "Saturn Award"), and "The Big
Goodbye" (S1E12) won a [Peabody Award](/wiki/Peabody_Award "Peabody Award").
Some of the highest rated shows by Nielsen ratings were the pilot, the finale,
"Unification" (duology), "Aquiel", "A Matter of Time", and "Relics".
"Unification" includes the classic characters Spock and his father Sarek, and
"Relics" includes Scotty. Other famous episodes include the "Best of Both
Worlds" duology, "Inner Light", and "The Measure of Man", which was released
in a 1080p extended version in 2012.

The series follows the adventures of a space-faring crew on board the [Galaxy
Class](/wiki/Galaxy_Class "Galaxy Class") starship [USS  _Enterprise_
(NCC-1701-D)](/wiki/USS_Enterprise_\(NCC-1701-D\) "USS Enterprise
\(NCC-1701-D\)"), the fifth Federation vessel to bear the name and registry
and the seventh starship by that name. (See [Starship
_Enterprise_](/wiki/Starship_Enterprise "Starship Enterprise") for other ships
with the name and/or registry). The series is set about 70 years after the
final mission of the original _Enterprise_ crew under the command of [James T.
Kirk](/wiki/James_T._Kirk "James T. Kirk").[6] The Federation has undergone
significant internal changes in its quest to explore and seek out new life,
adding new degrees of complexity and controversy to its methods, especially
those focused on the [Prime Directive](/wiki/Prime_Directive "Prime
Directive"). The [Klingon Empire](/wiki/Klingon "Klingon") and the [United
Federation of Planets](/wiki/United_Federation_of_Planets "United Federation
of Planets") have ceased wartime hostilities and become galactic allies, while
more sinister foes such as the [Romulans](/wiki/Romulan "Romulan") and the
[Borg](/wiki/Borg_\(Star_Trek\) "Borg \(Star Trek\)") take precedence on the
series.

The _Enterprise_ is commanded by Captain [Jean-Luc Picard](/wiki/Jean-
Luc_Picard "Jean-Luc Picard") and is staffed by first officer Commander
[William Riker](/wiki/William_Riker "William Riker"), second
officer/operations manager [Data](/wiki/Data_\(Star_Trek\) "Data \(Star
Trek\)"), security chief [Tasha Yar](/wiki/Tasha_Yar "Tasha Yar"), ship's
counselor [Deanna Troi](/wiki/Deanna_Troi "Deanna Troi"), [chief medical
officer](/wiki/Chief_medical_officer "Chief medical officer") Dr. [Beverly
Crusher](/wiki/Beverly_Crusher "Beverly Crusher") and her son [Wesley
Crusher](/wiki/Wesley_Crusher "Wesley Crusher"), conn officer Lieutenant
[Geordi La Forge](/wiki/Geordi_La_Forge "Geordi La Forge"), and junior officer
Lieutenant [Worf](/wiki/Worf "Worf"). The death of Lieutenant Yar in the
twenty-third episode of the first season (1987-1988) of the series prompts an
internal shuffle of personnel, making Worf official chief of security. In
season two, La Forge is promoted to chief engineer and [Katherine
Pulaski](/wiki/Katherine_Pulaski "Katherine Pulaski") briefly takes over for
Beverly Crusher.

The series begins with the crew of the _Enterprise_ -D put on trial by an
omnipotent being known as [Q](/wiki/Q_\(Star_Trek\) "Q \(Star Trek\)"), who
became a recurring character. The god-like entity threatens the extinction of
mankind for being a race of savages, forcing them to solve a mystery at nearby
Farpoint Station to prove their worthiness to be spared. After successfully
solving the mystery and avoiding disaster, the crew officially departs on its
mission to explore strange new worlds.

Subsequent stories focus on the discovery of new life and sociological and
political relationships with alien cultures, as well as exploring the [human
condition](/wiki/Human_condition "Human condition"). Several new species are
introduced as recurring antagonists, including the [Ferengi](/wiki/Ferengi
"Ferengi"), the [Cardassians](/wiki/Cardassian "Cardassian"), and the
[Borg](/wiki/Borg_\(Star_Trek\) "Borg \(Star Trek\)"). Throughout their
adventures, Picard and his crew are often forced to face and live with the
consequences of difficult choices.

The series ended in its seventh season with a two-part episode "All Good
Things...", which brought the events of the series full circle to the original
confrontation with Q. An interstellar anomaly that threatens all life in the
universe forces Picard to leap from his present, past, and future to combat
the threat. Picard was successfully able to show to Q that humanity could
think outside of the confines of perception and theorize on new possibilities
while still being prepared to sacrifice themselves for the sake of the greater
good. The series ended with the crew of the _Enterprise_ portrayed as feeling
more like a family and paved the way for four consecutive motion pictures that
continued the theme and mission of the series.

###
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Background")]

By 1986, 20 years after _Star Trek_ 's debut on [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC"), the
franchise's longevity amazed [Paramount Pictures](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures
"Paramount Pictures") executives. Chairman [Frank Mancuso
Sr.](/wiki/Frank_Mancuso_Sr. "Frank Mancuso Sr.") and others described it as
the studio's "crown jewel", a "priceless asset" that "must not be squandered".
The series was the most popular [syndicated](/wiki/Broadcast_syndication
"Broadcast syndication") television program 17 years after cancellation,[8]
and the [Harve Bennett](/wiki/Harve_Bennett "Harve Bennett")-produced [_Star
Trek_ films](/wiki/Star_Trek_\(film_franchise\) "Star Trek \(film
franchise\)") did well at the box office.[9] [William
Shatner](/wiki/William_Shatner "William Shatner") and [Leonard
Nimoy](/wiki/Leonard_Nimoy "Leonard Nimoy")'s salary demands for _[Star Trek
IV: The Voyage Home](/wiki/Star_Trek_IV:_The_Voyage_Home "Star Trek IV: The
Voyage Home")_ (1986) caused the studio to plan for a new _Star Trek_
television series, as it had thought to do in 1977 with _[Star Trek: Phase
II](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Phase_II "Star Trek: Phase II")_ before making the films.
Paramount executives worried that a new show could hurt the demand for the
films, but decided that it would increase their appeal on videocassette and
cable,[8] and that a show with unknown actors would be more profitable than
paying the films' actors' large salaries.[10] Roddenberry initially declined
to be involved, but came on board as creator after being unhappy with early
conceptual work. _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ was announced on October 10,
1986,[6] and its cast in May 1987.[11]

Paramount executive Rick Berman was assigned to the show at Roddenberry's
request. Roddenberry hired a number of _Star Trek_ veterans, including [Bob
Justman](/wiki/Robert_H._Justman "Robert H. Justman"), [D. C.
Fontana](/wiki/D._C._Fontana "D. C. Fontana"), Eddie Milkis, and [David
Gerrold](/wiki/David_Gerrold "David Gerrold").[12] Early proposals for the
series included one in which some of the original series cast might appear as
"elder statesmen",[8] and Roddenberry speculated as late as October 1986 that
the new series might not even use a spaceship, as "people might travel by some
[other] means" 100 years after the [USS  _Enterprise_
(NCC-1701)](/wiki/USS_Enterprise_\(NCC-1701\) "USS Enterprise
\(NCC-1701\)").[13] A more lasting change was his new belief that workplace
interpersonal conflict would no longer exist in the future; thus, the new
series did not have parallels to the frequent "crusty banter" between Kirk,
[Spock](/wiki/Spock "Spock"), and [Leonard McCoy](/wiki/Leonard_McCoy "Leonard
McCoy").[10] According to series actor Patrick Stewart, Berman was more
receptive than Roddenberry to the show addressing political issues.[14]

The series' music theme combined the fanfare from the original series theme by
[Alexander Courage](/wiki/Alexander_Courage "Alexander Courage") with [Jerry
Goldsmith](/wiki/Jerry_Goldsmith "Jerry Goldsmith")'s theme for _[Star Trek:
The Motion Picture](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Motion_Picture "Star Trek: The Motion
Picture")_ (1979). Some early episodes' plots derived from outlines created
for _Star Trek: Phase II_.[6] Additionally, some sets used in the _Original
Series_ -era films were redressed for _The Next Generation_ , and in turn used
for subsequent _Original Series_ films.[15] Part of the transporter room set
in _TNG_ was used in the original _Star Trek_ 's transporter set.[15] Many
production details, such as [LCARS](/wiki/LCARS "LCARS") computer interfaces
and starship design, were carried through in the production of subsequent
spin-offs.

A major focus of the show is the faster-than-light starship visiting
[exoplanets](/wiki/Exoplanet "Exoplanet"), which, although some had speculated
to exist, were still in the realm of science fiction when show started in the
1987. However, by the early 1990s more claims were coming out including for
[PSR B1257+12](/wiki/PSR_B1257%2B12 "PSR B1257+12"), and a year after the show
ended there was a more definitive detection of planets around [51
Pegasi](/wiki/51_Pegasi "51 Pegasi"). Another example is the ubiquitous use of
hand-held tablet computers, at the time a fictional technology props for the
actors but became a more practical and common computing device by the 2010s

### Syndication and
profitability[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Syndication and profitability")]

Despite _Star Trek_ 's proven success, NBC and ABC only offered to consider
pilot scripts for the new series, and CBS offered to air a [miniseries that
could become a series](/wiki/Backdoor_pilot "Backdoor pilot") if it did well.
That the [Big Three television networks](/wiki/Big_Three_television_networks
"Big Three television networks") treated Paramount's most appealing and
valuable property as they would any other series offended the studio.
[Fox](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company") wanted the
show to help launch the new network, but wanted it by March 1987, and would
only commit to 13 episodes instead of a full season. The unsuccessful
negotiations convinced the studio that it could only protect _Star Trek_ with
full control.[8][13]

Paramount increased and accelerated the show's profitability by choosing to
instead broadcast it in [first-run syndication](/wiki/First-run_syndication
"First-run syndication")[16][10][17]:123–124 on [independent
stations](/wiki/Independent_station_\(North_America\) "Independent station
\(North America\)") (whose numbers had more than tripled since 1980) and Big
Three [network affiliates](/wiki/Network_affiliate "Network affiliate").[8]
The studio offered the show to local stations for free as [barter
syndication](/wiki/Barter_syndication "Barter syndication"). The stations sold
five minutes of commercial time to local advertisers and Paramount sold the
remaining seven minutes to national advertisers. Stations had to commit to
purchasing reruns in the future,[16] and only those that aired the new show
could purchase the popular reruns of the original series.[18]:222[19]

The studio's strategy succeeded. Most of the 150 stations airing reruns of the
original _Star Trek_ wanted to prevent a competitor from airing the new show;
ultimately, 210 stations covering 90% of the United States became part of
Paramount's informal nationwide network for _TNG_.[16][20] In early October
1987, more than 50 network affiliates pre-empted their own shows for the
series pilot, "[Encounter at Farpoint](/wiki/Encounter_at_Farpoint "Encounter
at Farpoint")". One station predicted that "'Star Trek' promises to be one of
the most successful programs of the season, network or syndicated."[20] TNG
helped stations like [WZZM](/wiki/WZZM "WZZM") in [Grand Rapids,
Michigan](/wiki/Grand_Rapids,_Michigan "Grand Rapids, Michigan"), who made a
decision show _The Next Generation_.[20]

The new show indeed performed well; the pilot's ratings were higher than those
of many network programs,[20] and ratings remained comparable to network shows
by the end of the first season, despite the handicap of each station airing
the show on a different day and time, often outside prime time. By the end of
the first season, Paramount reportedly received $1 million for advertising per
episode, more than the roughly $800,000 fee that networks typically paid for a
one-hour show;[16] by 1992, when the budget for each episode had risen to
almost $2 million,[21] the studio earned $90 million from advertising annually
from first-run episodes, with each 30-second commercial selling for $115,000
to $150,000.[22][23] The show had a 40% [return on
investment](/wiki/Return_on_investment "Return on investment") for Paramount,
with $30 to $60 million in annual upfront net profit for first-run episodes
and another $70 million for [stripping](/wiki/Stripping_\(television\)
"Stripping \(television\)") rights for each of the about 100 episodes then
available, so did not need overseas sales to be successful.[22]

### Season
one[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Season one")]

Main article: [Star Trek: The Next Generation (season
1)](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation_\(season_1\) "Star Trek: The Next
Generation \(season 1\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Gates_with_Denise_August_2017.jpg/220px-
Gates_with_Denise_August_2017.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gates_with_Denise_August_2017.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gates_with_Denise_August_2017.jpg "Enlarge")

Gates and Denise were in Season 1 as Doctor Crusher and Tasha Yar,
respectively, but were removed for Season 2.

_The Next Generation_ was shot on 35mm film,[24] and the budget for each
episode was $1.3 million, among the largest for a one-hour television
drama.[16] While the staff enjoyed the creative freedom gained by independence
from a broadcast network's [Standards and
Practices](/wiki/Standards_and_Practices "Standards and Practices")
department,[18]:222 the first season was marked by a "revolving door" of
writers, with Gerrold, [Fontana](/wiki/D._C._Fontana "D. C. Fontana"), and
others quitting after disputes with Roddenberry.[25] Roddenberry "virtually
rewrote" the first 15 episodes because of his "dogmatic" intention to depict
human interaction "without drawing on the baser motives of greed, lust, and
power". Writers found the show's "[bible](/wiki/Bible_\(writing\) "Bible
\(writing\)")" constricting and ridiculous and couldn't deal with
Roddenberry's ego and treatment of them. It stated, for example, that "regular
characters all share a feeling of being part of a band of brothers and
sisters. As in the original 'Star Trek,' we invite the audience to share the
same feeling of affection for our characters."[10]

Mark Bourne of _The DVD Journal_ wrote of season one: "A typical episode
relied on trite plot points, clumsy allegories, dry and stilted dialogue, or
characterization that was taking too long to feel relaxed and natural."[26]
Other targets of criticism included poor [special
effects](/wiki/Special_effect "Special effect") and plots being resolved by
the _[deus ex machina](/wiki/Deus_ex_machina "Deus ex machina")_ of [Wesley
Crusher](/wiki/Wesley_Crusher "Wesley Crusher") saving the ship.[27][28]
However, [Patrick Stewart](/wiki/Patrick_Stewart "Patrick Stewart")'s acting
skills won praise, and critics noted that characters were given greater
potential for development than those of the original series.[26][27] Both
actors and producers were unsure whether [Trekkies](/wiki/Trekkie "Trekkie")
loyal to the original show would accept the new one,[29][30] but one critic
stated as early as October 1987 that _The Next Generation_ , not the movies or
the original show, "is the real 'Star Trek' now".[31]

While the events of most episodes of season one were self-contained, many
developments important to the show as a whole occurred during the season. The
recurring nemesis [Q](/wiki/Q_\(Star_Trek\) "Q \(Star Trek\)") was introduced
in the pilot, the alien Ferengi had their sentinel showing in "[The Last
Outpost](/wiki/The_Last_Outpost_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Last
Outpost \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", the [holodeck](/wiki/Holodeck
"Holodeck") was introduced, and the romantic backstory between [William
Riker](/wiki/William_Riker "William Riker") and [Deanna
Troi](/wiki/Deanna_Troi "Deanna Troi") was investigated. "[The Naked
Now](/wiki/The_Naked_Now "The Naked Now")", one of the few episodes that
depicted Roddenberry's fascination (as seen in the show's bible) with sex in
the future, became a cast favorite.[10]

Later episodes in the season set the stage for serial plots. The episode
"[Datalore](/wiki/Datalore "Datalore")" introduced Data's [evil
twin](/wiki/Evil_twin "Evil twin") brother [Lore](/wiki/Lore_\(Star_Trek\)
"Lore \(Star Trek\)"), who made several more appearances in episodes in
subsequent seasons. "[Coming of
Age](/wiki/Coming_of_Age_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Coming of Age
\(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" dealt with Wesley Crusher's efforts to
get into [Starfleet Academy](/wiki/Starfleet_Academy "Starfleet Academy")
while also hinting at the threat to Starfleet later faced in
"[Conspiracy](/wiki/Conspiracy_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Conspiracy
\(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")". "[Heart of Glory](/wiki/Heart_of_Glory
"Heart of Glory")" explored Worf's character, [Klingon](/wiki/Klingon
"Klingon") culture, and the uneasy truce between the Federation and the
Klingon Empire, three themes that played major roles in later episodes. Tasha
Yar left the show in "[Skin of Evil](/wiki/Skin_of_Evil "Skin of Evil")",
becoming the first regular Star Trek character to die permanently (although
the character was seen again in two later episodes) in either series or film.
The season finale, "[The Neutral
Zone](/wiki/The_Neutral_Zone_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Neutral
Zone \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", established the presence of two of
_TNG_ ' most enduring villains: the Romulans, making their first appearance
since the _Original Series_ , and, through foreshadowing, the Borg.

The premiere became the first television episode to be nominated for a [Hugo
Award](/wiki/Hugo_Award "Hugo Award") since 1972. Six of the season's episodes
were each nominated for an [Emmy Award](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award").
"[11001001](/wiki/11001001 "11001001")" won for Outstanding Sound Editing for
a Series, "[The Big Goodbye](/wiki/The_Big_Goodbye "The Big Goodbye")" won for
Outstanding Costume Design for a Series, and
"[Conspiracy](/wiki/Conspiracy_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Conspiracy
\(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" won for Outstanding Achievement in
Makeup for a Series.[6] "The Big Goodbye" also won a [Peabody
Award](/wiki/Peabody_Award "Peabody Award"), the first syndicated program[16]
and only _Star Trek_ episode to do so.

The top episodes for Nielsen ratings were "Encounter at Farpoint" with 15.7,
and the next highest was "Justice" with 12.7.[32]

_Debuted 1987-1988_

### Season
two[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Season two")]

Main article: [Star Trek: The Next Generation (season
2)](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation_\(season_2\) "Star Trek: The Next
Generation \(season 2\)")

The series underwent significant changes during its second season. [Beverly
Crusher](/wiki/Beverly_Crusher "Beverly Crusher") was replaced as Chief
Medical Officer by [Katherine Pulaski](/wiki/Katherine_Pulaski "Katherine
Pulaski"), played by [Diana Muldaur](/wiki/Diana_Muldaur "Diana Muldaur"), who
had been a guest star in "[Return to Tomorrow](/wiki/Return_to_Tomorrow
"Return to Tomorrow")" and "[Is There in Truth No
Beauty?](/wiki/Is_There_in_Truth_No_Beauty%3F "Is There in Truth No
Beauty?")", two episodes from the original _Star Trek_ series. The ship's
recreational area, Ten-Forward, and its mysterious bartender/advisor,
[Guinan](/wiki/Guinan_\(Star_Trek\) "Guinan \(Star Trek\)"), played by [Whoopi
Goldberg](/wiki/Whoopi_Goldberg "Whoopi Goldberg"), appeared for the first
time. Another change was in the opening theme, wherein at the end is a short
fanfare. Owing to the [1988 Writers Guild of America
strike](/wiki/1988_Writers_Guild_of_America_strike "1988 Writers Guild of
America strike"), the number of episodes produced was cut from 26 to 22, and
the start of the season was delayed. Because of the strike, the opening
episode, "[The Child](/wiki/The_Child_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The
Child \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", was based on a script originally
written for _[Star Trek: Phase II](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Phase_II "Star Trek: Phase
II")_ , while the season finale, "[Shades of
Gray](/wiki/Shades_of_Gray_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Shades of Gray
\(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", was a [clip show](/wiki/Clip_show "Clip
show").

Nevertheless, season two as a whole was widely regarded as significantly
better than season one.[33] Benefiting from Paramount's commitment to a
multiyear run and free from network interference due to syndication,
Roddenberry found writers who could work within his guidelines and create
drama from the cast's interaction with the rest of the universe.[10] The plots
became more sophisticated and began to mix drama with comic relief. Its focus
on character development received special praise.[33] Co-executive producer
Maurice Hurley has stated that his primary goal for the season was to plan and
execute season-long [story arcs](/wiki/Story_arc "Story arc") and [character
arcs](/wiki/Character_arc "Character arc").[34] Hurley wrote the acclaimed
episode "[Q Who](/wiki/Q_Who "Q Who")", which featured the first on-screen
appearance of the Borg, _TNG_ 's most popular villain. Season two focused on
developing the character Data, and two highly regarded episodes from the
season, "[Elementary, Dear Data](/wiki/Elementary,_Dear_Data "Elementary, Dear
Data")" and "[The Measure of a
Man](/wiki/The_Measure_of_a_Man_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The
Measure of a Man \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", featured him
prominently.[35] [Miles O'Brien](/wiki/Miles_O%27Brien_\(Star_Trek\) "Miles
O'Brien \(Star Trek\)") also became a more prominent character during the
second season, while [Geordi La Forge](/wiki/Geordi_La_Forge "Geordi La
Forge") took the position of Chief Engineer. Klingon issues continued to be
explored in well-regarded episodes such as "[A Matter of
Honor](/wiki/A_Matter_of_Honor "A Matter of Honor")" and "[The
Emissary](/wiki/The_Emissary_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Emissary
\(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", which introduced Worf's former lover
[K'Ehleyr](/wiki/K%27Ehleyr "K'Ehleyr").[36] Five second-season episodes were
nominated for six Emmy Awards, and "Q Who" won for Outstanding Sound Editing
for a Series and Outstanding Sound Mixing for a Drama Series.[6]

_Debuted 1988-1989_

### Season
three[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Season three")]

Main article: [Star Trek: The Next Generation (season
3)](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation_\(season_3\) "Star Trek: The Next
Generation \(season 3\)")

Before the production of the third season in the summer of 1989, some
personnel changes were made. Head writer Maurice Hurley was let go and
[Michael Piller](/wiki/Michael_Piller "Michael Piller") took over for the rest
of the series. Creator and executive producer Gene Roddenberry took less of an
active role due to his declining health. Roddenberry gave Piller and Berman
the executive producer jobs, and they remained in that position for the rest
of the series' run, with Berman overseeing the production as a whole and
Piller being in charge of the creative direction of the show and the writing
room. Doctor Crusher returned from her off-screen tenure at Starfleet Medical
to replace Doctor Pulaski, who had remained a guest star throughout the second
season. An additional change was the inclusion of the fanfare that was added
to the opening credits of the second season, to the end of the closing
credits. [Ronald D. Moore](/wiki/Ronald_D._Moore "Ronald D. Moore") joined the
show after submitting a [spec script](/wiki/Spec_script "Spec script") that
became "[The Bonding](/wiki/The_Bonding "The Bonding")". He became the
franchise's "[Klingon](/wiki/Klingon "Klingon") guru",[6] meaning that he
wrote most _TNG_ episodes dealing with the Klingon Empire (though he wrote
some Romulan stories, as well, such as "[The
Defector](/wiki/The_Defector_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Defector
\(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")"). Writer/producer [Ira Steven
Behr](/wiki/Ira_Steven_Behr "Ira Steven Behr") also joined the show in its
third season. Though his tenure with _TNG_ lasted only one year, he later went
on to be a writer and showrunner of spin-off series _[Star Trek: Deep Space
Nine](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Deep_Space_Nine "Star Trek: Deep Space Nine")_.[37] Six
third-season episodes were nominated for eight Emmys. "[Yesterday's
Enterprise](/wiki/Yesterday%27s_Enterprise "Yesterday's Enterprise")" won for
Outstanding Sound Editing for a Series and "[Sins of the
Father](/wiki/Sins_of_the_Father_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Sins of
the Father \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" won for Best Art Direction
for a Series.[6] After a chiropractor warned that the cast members risked
permanent skeletal injury, new two-piece wool uniforms replaced the first two
seasons' extremely tight spandex uniforms.[38] The season finale, the
critically acclaimed episode "[The Best of Both
Worlds](/wiki/The_Best_of_Both_Worlds_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The
Best of Both Worlds \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", was the first
season-ending [cliffhanger](/wiki/Cliffhanger "Cliffhanger"), a tradition that
continued throughout the remainder of the series.

_Debuted 1989-1990_

### Season
four[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Season four")]

Main article: [Star Trek: The Next Generation (season
4)](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation_\(season_4\) "Star Trek: The Next
Generation \(season 4\)")

[Brannon Braga](/wiki/Brannon_Braga "Brannon Braga") and [Jeri
Taylor](/wiki/Jeri_Taylor "Jeri Taylor") joined the show in its fourth season.
The fourth season surpassed the _Original Series_ in series length with the
production of "The Best of Both Worlds, Part II". A new alien race, the
Cardassians, made their first appearance in "The Wounded". They later were
featured in _Star Trek: Deep Space Nine_. The season finale, "Redemption", was
the 100th episode, and the cast and crew (including creator Gene Roddenberry)
celebrated the historic milestone on the bridge set. Footage of this was seen
in the _Star Trek_ 25th-anniversary special hosted by William Shatner and
Leonard Nimoy which aired later in the year. Seven fourth-season episodes were
nominated for eight Emmys. "[The Best of Both Worlds, Part
II](/wiki/The_Best_of_Both_Worlds_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Best
of Both Worlds \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" won for both Outstanding
Sound Editing in a Series and Outstanding Sound Mixing for a Series.[6]
Character Wesley Crusher left the series in season four to go to Starfleet
Academy. "[Family](/wiki/Family_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Family
\(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" was the only _Star Trek_ episode not to
have a bridge scene during the entire episode and is the only _TNG_ episode
where Data does not appear on-screen.

_Debuted 1990-1991_

### Season
five[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Season five")]

Main article: [Star Trek: The Next Generation (season
5)](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation_\(season_5\) "Star Trek: The Next
Generation \(season 5\)")

The fifth season's seventh episode,
"[Unification](/wiki/Unification_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\)
"Unification \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", opened with a dedication
to _Star Trek_ creator [Gene Roddenberry](/wiki/Gene_Roddenberry "Gene
Roddenberry") (though the prior episode, "The Game", aired four days after his
death). Roddenberry, though he had recently died, continued to be credited as
executive producer for the rest of the season. The cast and crew learned of
his death during the production of "[Hero
Worship](/wiki/Hero_Worship_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Hero Worship
\(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", a later season-five episode. Seven
fifth-season episodes were nominated for eight Emmys. "[Cost of
Living](/wiki/Cost_of_Living_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Cost of
Living \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" won for Outstanding Individual
Achievement in Costume Design for a Series and Outstanding Individual
Achievement in Makeup for a Series, and "[A Matter of
Time](/wiki/A_Matter_of_Time_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "A Matter of
Time \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" and
"[Conundrum](/wiki/Conundrum_\(Star_Trek:_the_Next_Generation\) "Conundrum
\(Star Trek: the Next Generation\)")" tied for Outstanding Individual
Achievement in Special Visual Effects. In addition, "[The Inner
Light](/wiki/The_Inner_Light_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Inner
Light \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" became the first television
episode since the 1968 original series _Star Trek_ episode "[The City on the
Edge of Forever](/wiki/The_City_on_the_Edge_of_Forever "The City on the Edge
of Forever")" to win a [Hugo Award](/wiki/Hugo_Award "Hugo Award") for Best
Dramatic Presentation.[6] Season five had the introduction of a jacket for
Picard, worn periodically throughout the rest of the show's run. The
observation lounge set was altered with the removal of the gold model
starships across the interior wall and the addition of lighting beneath the
windows. Recurring character Ensign [Ro Laren](/wiki/Ro_Laren "Ro Laren") was
introduced in the fifth season. The season 5 finale cliffhanger includes a
cameo by [Stephen Hawking](/wiki/Stephen_Hawking "Stephen Hawking") (Part I of
"Descent").

_Debuted 1991-1992_

### Season
six[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Season six")]

Main article: [Star Trek: The Next Generation (season
6)](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation_\(season_6\) "Star Trek: The Next
Generation \(season 6\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Mae_Jemison_in_Space.jpg/220px-
Mae_Jemison_in_Space.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mae_Jemison_in_Space.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mae_Jemison_in_Space.jpg "Enlarge")

NASA Astronaut [Mae Jemison](/wiki/Mae_Jemison "Mae Jemison"), shown here on a
Space Shuttle mission is featured in "Second Chances" (S6E24) as a Lieutenant
on the Enterprise-D

The sixth season brought a new set of changes. Rick Berman and Michael
Piller's time was split between the newly created _[Star Trek: Deep Space
Nine](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Deep_Space_Nine "Star Trek: Deep Space Nine")_ and _The
Next Generation_. Three sixth-season episodes were nominated for Emmys.
"[Time's Arrow, Part
II](/wiki/Time%27s_Arrow_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Time's Arrow
\(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" won for both Outstanding Individual
Achievement in Costume Design for a Series and Outstanding Individual
Achievement in Hairstyling for a Series, and "[A Fistful of
Datas](/wiki/A_Fistful_of_Datas "A Fistful of Datas")" won for Outstanding
Individual Achievement in Sound Mixing for a Drama Series.[6] The highest
rated episode of Season 6 for Nielsen ratings was "Relics", with a rating of
13.9.[39] which featured Scotty played by original series veteran [James
Doohan](/wiki/James_Doohan "James Doohan").

NASA astronaut [Mae Jemison](/wiki/Mae_Jemison "Mae Jemison") plays in Lt.
Palmer the Season 6 show "Second Chances".[40][41]

_Debuted 1992-1993_

### Season
seven[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Season seven")]

Main article: [Star Trek: The Next Generation (season
7)](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation_\(season_7\) "Star Trek: The Next
Generation \(season 7\)")

The seventh season was _The Next Generation_ 's last. The penultimate episode,
"[Preemptive
Strike](/wiki/Preemptive_Strike_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Preemptive
Strike \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", concluded the plot line for the
recurring character Ensign [Ro Laren](/wiki/Ro_Laren "Ro Laren") and
introduced themes that continued in _Star Trek: Deep Space Nine_ and _Star
Trek: Voyager_. _The Next Generation_ series finale, "[All Good
Things...](/wiki/All_Good_Things..._\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "All
Good Things... \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", was a double-length
episode (separated into two parts for reruns) that aired the week of May 19,
1994, revisiting the events of the pilot and providing a bookend to the
series. Toronto's [SkyDome](/wiki/SkyDome "SkyDome") played host to a massive
event for the series finale. Thousands of people packed the stadium to watch
the final episode on the stadium's [JumboTron](/wiki/JumboTron "JumboTron").
Five seventh-season episodes were nominated for nine Emmys, and the series as
a whole was the first syndicated television series nominated for Outstanding
Drama Series. To this day, _The Next Generation_ is the only syndicated drama
to be nominated in this category. "All Good Things..." won for Outstanding
Individual Achievement in Special Visual Effects, and
"[Genesis](/wiki/Genesis_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Genesis \(Star
Trek: The Next Generation\)")" won for Outstanding Individual Achievement in
Sound Mixing for a Drama Series. "All Good Things..." also won the second of
the series's two Hugo Awards.[6] "All Good Things.." also achieved the highest
Nielson rating for all of Season 7, with a rating of 17.4.[42]

The TNG cast went on to make 4 films after the conclusion of Season 7. Between
1994 and 2002 the main Cast of the show went on to star in Generations, First
Contact, Insurrection, and Nemesis. Meanwhile, on TV, DS9 continued with some
of the prior TNG cast including Worf and O'Brien, and later in Fall of 1994
Frakes (TNG's Riker) guest starred on Deep Space Nine's
"[Defiant](/wiki/Defiant_\(Star_Trek:_Deep_Space_Nine\) "Defiant \(Star Trek:
Deep Space Nine\)")" (S3E9). In January 1995 the new Star Trek TV series
Voyager show launched. and the aforementioned Generations movie had hit
theaters in November 1994. Even with the loss of the franchise's guide and
visionary, Roddenberry, Star Trek: The Next Generation had launched a golden
era of new Trek media which would last well into the 21st century. In the
finale of Enterprise, over ten years later Frakes and Sirtis reprising their
roles as Riker and Deanna appear on television one last time. In the 2010s a
project would be undertaken to convert all of TNG to 1080p High-Definition,
and by 2015 it was all released on Blue-Ray, TV, and HD internet steaming
services.

_Debuted 1993-1994_

###
Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Legacy")]

Although the cast members were contracted for eight seasons,[43]
[Paramount](/wiki/Paramount_Pictures "Paramount Pictures") ended _The Next
Generation_ after seven, which disappointed and puzzled some of the actors,
and was an unusual decision for a successful television show. Paramount then
made films using the cast, which it believed would be less successful if the
show were still on television.[44] Season eight also would likely have reduced
the show's profitability due to higher cast salaries and a lower price per
episode when sold for [stripping](/wiki/Strip_programming "Strip
programming"). The show's strong ratings continued to the end; the series
finale was ranked number two among all shows that week, between hits _[Home
Improvement](/wiki/Home_Improvement_\(TV_series\) "Home Improvement \(TV
series\)")_ and _[Seinfeld](/wiki/Seinfeld "Seinfeld")_.[43]

Star Trek: The Next Generation finale in Season Seven was watched by over 30
million viewers when it concluded in early 1994.[4] TNG would provide the
high-water mark in terms of viewership, with a peak of 11.5 million during its
5th Season prior to the launch of DS9, and between 1988 and 1992 it picked up
half a million to a million additional viewers per year.[5]

Adjusted Nielson Ratings for Star Trek TV[5]

  * Fall 1987 - Spring 1988: 8.55 Million TNG S1
  * Fall 1988 - Spring 1989: 9.14 Million TNG S2
  * Fall 1989 - Spring 1990: 9.77 Million TNG S3
  * Fall 1990 - Spring 1991: 10.58 Million TNG S4
  * Fall 1991 - Spring 1992: 11.50 Million TNG S5
  * Fall 1992 - Spring 1993: 10.83 Million TNG S6 (DS9 S1 Debuted in Spring 1993)
  * Fall 1993 - Spring 1994: 9.78 Million TNG S7 + DS9 S2
  * Fall 1994 - Spring 1995: 7.05 Million DS9 S3 + VOY S1
  * Fall 1995 - Spring 1996: 6.42 Million DS9 S4 + VOY S2
  * Fall 1996 - Spring 1997: 5.03 Million DS9 S5 + VOY S3
  * Fall 1997 - Spring 1998: 4.53 Million DS9 S6+ VOY S4
  * Fall 1998 - Spring 1999: 4.00 Million DS9 S7 + VOY S5 (Voyager also had two more seasons)

## High-Definition
Project[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: High-Definition Project")]

In the 2010s, _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ was re-produced in high-
definition (1080p) with a format of 4:3 (1.33:1).[45] Many thought would not
be possible, but CBS managed to do it and major work was done at CBS
Digital.[45] TNG was shot on 35 mm film, which meant the film could be re-
scanned to a higher resolution, however, many of the special effects had to be
re-produced.[46] Also a 7.1 DTS-HD Master Audio sound option was created.[46]

Season 1 achieved 95,000 units in its launch week in 2012.[47] (further
information [Blu-Ray releases](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation#Blu-ray
"Star Trek: The Next Generation")) In addition to the Blu-Ray packages, the HD
was sold to many online streaming TV providers such as Netflix.[48] The
Netflix version included some additional special effect changes.[48] The Blu-
ray sets include many special features and videos, such as a 1988 episode of
[Reading Rainbow](/wiki/Reading_Rainbow "Reading Rainbow") where Levar Burton
(on TNG he is cast as Chief Engineer Geordi) documents the making of a Star
Trek: The Next Generation episode.[46]

In June 2016 a 41-disc set was released with over 8000 minutes of TNG-content,
including the entire show in 1080p (4:3).[49]

Whoopi Goldberg portrays Guinan

  * [Patrick Stewart](/wiki/Patrick_Stewart "Patrick Stewart") as Captain [Jean-Luc Picard](/wiki/Jean-Luc_Picard "Jean-Luc Picard") is the commanding officer of the U.S.S. _Enterprise_. Stewart also played the character in the pilot episode of _Deep Space Nine_ and all four TNG theater films
  * [Jonathan Frakes](/wiki/Jonathan_Frakes "Jonathan Frakes") as Commander [William Riker](/wiki/William_Riker "William Riker") is the ship's first officer. The Riker character was influenced by concepts for first officer Willard Decker in the _[Star Trek: Phase II](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Phase_II "Star Trek: Phase II")_ television series.[6] Decker's romantic history with helmsman Ilia was mirrored in _The Next Generation_ in the relationship between Riker and Deanna Troi.[6] Riker also appears in an episode each of _[Star Trek: Voyager](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Voyager "Star Trek: Voyager")_ and _[Star Trek: Enterprise](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Enterprise "Star Trek: Enterprise")_. In addition to William Riker, Frakes played William's [transporter](/wiki/Transporter_\(Star_Trek\) "Transporter \(Star Trek\)")-created double, Thomas, in one episode each of _The Next Generation_ and _Star Trek: Deep Space Nine_.
  * [LeVar Burton](/wiki/LeVar_Burton "LeVar Burton") as [Geordi La Forge](/wiki/Geordi_La_Forge "Geordi La Forge") was initially the ship's helmsman, but the character became chief engineer beginning in the second season. Burton also played the character in an episode of _Voyager_.
  * [Denise Crosby](/wiki/Denise_Crosby "Denise Crosby") as [Tasha Yar](/wiki/Tasha_Yar "Tasha Yar") is the chief of security and tactical officer. Crosby left the series at the end of the first season, and the Yar character was killed. Yar returns in alternate timelines in the award-winning episode "[Yesterday's Enterprise](/wiki/Yesterday%27s_Enterprise "Yesterday's Enterprise")" and the series finale, "[All Good Things...](/wiki/All_Good_Things..._\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "All Good Things... \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")". Crosby also played Commander Sela, Yar's half-[Romulan](/wiki/Romulan "Romulan") daughter.
  * [Michael Dorn](/wiki/Michael_Dorn "Michael Dorn") as [Worf](/wiki/Worf "Worf") is a Klingon. Worf initially appears as a junior officer fulfilling several roles on the bridge. When Denise Crosby left at the end of the first season, the Worf character succeeded Lieutenant Yar as the ship's chief of security and tactical officer. Dorn reprised the role as a regular in seasons four through seven of _Star Trek: Deep Space Nine_ and also played another Klingon, also named Worf, in _[Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country](/wiki/Star_Trek_VI:_The_Undiscovered_Country "Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country")_ ; with 282 on screen appearances, Dorn has the most appearances of any actor in the _Star Trek_ franchise.[50]
  * [Gates McFadden](/wiki/Gates_McFadden "Gates McFadden") as Doctor [Beverly Crusher](/wiki/Beverly_Crusher "Beverly Crusher") is the _Enterprise_ 's chief medical officer. As a fully certified bridge officer, Dr. Crusher had the ability to command the _Enterprise_ , if circumstances required her to do so. She also, on occasional, commanded night-watch shifts on the ship's main bridge to stay on top of starship operations. McFadden was fired after the first season, but was rehired for the third season[51] and remained for the remainder of the series.
  * [Diana Muldaur](/wiki/Diana_Muldaur "Diana Muldaur") as Doctor [Katherine Pulaski](/wiki/Katherine_Pulaski "Katherine Pulaski") was created to replace Dr. Crusher for the show's second season. Muldaur, who previously appeared in two episodes of the original _Star Trek_ , never received billing in the opening credits; instead, she was listed as a special guest star during the first act.
  * [Marina Sirtis](/wiki/Marina_Sirtis "Marina Sirtis") as Lieutenant Commander [Deanna Troi](/wiki/Deanna_Troi "Deanna Troi") is the half-human, half-[Betazoid](/wiki/Betazoid "Betazoid") ship's counselor. Starting in the season-seven7 episode "Thine Own Self", Counselor Troi, having taken and completed the bridge-officer's test, is later promoted to the rank of commander, which allowed her to take command of the ship, and also perform bridge duties other than those of a ship's counselor. The character's relationship with first officer Riker was a carry-over from character ideas developed for _Phase II_.[6] Troi also appeared in later episodes of _Voyager_ and in the finale of _Enterprise_.
  * [Brent Spiner](/wiki/Brent_Spiner "Brent Spiner") as Lieutenant Commander [Data](/wiki/Data_\(Star_Trek\) "Data \(Star Trek\)") is an [android](/wiki/Android_\(robot\) "Android \(robot\)") who serves as second officer and operations officer. Data's "outsider's" perspective on humanity served a similar narrative purpose as [Spock](/wiki/Spock "Spock")'s in the original _Star Trek_.[6] Spiner also played his "brother", [Lore](/wiki/Lore_\(Star_Trek\) "Lore \(Star Trek\)"), and his creator, [Noonien Soong](/wiki/Noonien_Soong "Noonien Soong"). In _Enterprise_ , Spiner played Noonien's ancestor, Arik, and contributed a brief voiceover (heard over the _Enterprise_ -D's intercom) in the _Enterprise_ finale.
  * [Wil Wheaton](/wiki/Wil_Wheaton "Wil Wheaton") as Beverly Crusher's son [Wesley](/wiki/Wesley_Crusher "Wesley Crusher") becomes an acting ensign, and later receives a field commission to ensign, before attending Starfleet Academy. After being a regular for the first four seasons, Wheaton appeared sporadically as Wesley Crusher for the remainder of the series.

In addition to the series regulars, other recurring characters include:

  * [Majel Barrett](/wiki/Majel_Barrett "Majel Barrett") as [Lwaxana Troi](/wiki/Lwaxana_Troi "Lwaxana Troi") is Deanna Troi's mother and Betazoid ambassador for the [United Federation of Planets](/wiki/United_Federation_of_Planets "United Federation of Planets"). She reprised her role in three episodes of _Deep Space Nine_. Barrett, married to _Star Trek_ creator Gene Roddenberry, previously appeared in the original _Star Trek_. She also voiced the computer in _The Next Generation_ and other spinoffs.
  * [Brian Bonsall](/wiki/Brian_Bonsall "Brian Bonsall") as [Alexander Rozhenko](/wiki/Alexander_Rozhenko "Alexander Rozhenko") is Worf's son. [Jon Paul Steuer](/wiki/Jon_Paul_Steuer "Jon Paul Steuer") played Alexander in the character's first appearance, and [James Sloyan](/wiki/James_Sloyan "James Sloyan") played an older, time-traveling version of Alexander in another episode. [Marc Worden](/wiki/Marc_Worden "Marc Worden") played the character for his appearances in _Deep Space Nine_.
  * [Rosalind Chao](/wiki/Rosalind_Chao "Rosalind Chao") as [Keiko O'Brien](/wiki/Keiko_O%27Brien "Keiko O'Brien") is Miles O'Brien's wife and a botanist. She also made recurring appearances in _Deep Space Nine_.
  * [John de Lancie](/wiki/John_de_Lancie "John de Lancie") as [Q](/wiki/Q_\(Star_Trek\) "Q \(Star Trek\)") is an omnipotent antagonist from the [Q Continuum](/wiki/Q_Continuum "Q Continuum"). de Lancie continued playing the Q character in both _Deep Space Nine_ and _Voyager_.
  * [Whoopi Goldberg](/wiki/Whoopi_Goldberg "Whoopi Goldberg") as [Guinan](/wiki/Guinan_\(Star_Trek\) "Guinan \(Star Trek\)") is the [El-Aurian](/wiki/El-Aurian "El-Aurian") [bartender](/wiki/Bartender "Bartender") in the ship's Ten Forward Lounge.
  * [Michelle Forbes](/wiki/Michelle_Forbes "Michelle Forbes") as Ensign [Ro Laren](/wiki/Ro_Laren "Ro Laren") is a [Bajoran](/wiki/Bajoran "Bajoran") helmsman, who is later promoted to the rank of lieutenant in season seven. That same season, however, she resigns from Starfleet to become a member of a group of renegade federation colonists known as "the Maquis". Forbes' character was considered for use in _Deep Space Nine_ , although producers eventually developed a new character, [Kira Nerys](/wiki/Kira_Nerys "Kira Nerys").[52]
  * [Colm Meaney](/wiki/Colm_Meaney "Colm Meaney") as [Miles O'Brien](/wiki/Miles_O%27Brien_\(Star_Trek\) "Miles O'Brien \(Star Trek\)") is an unnamed helmsman in the show's pilot, and appears several times in other positions during the first season. The character was eventually given a rank of Chief Petty Officer, and developed into the transporter chief. Meaney portrayed O'Brien for seven seasons as a series regular on _Deep Space Nine_.
  * [Robert O'Reilly](/wiki/Robert_O%27Reilly "Robert O'Reilly") as [Gowron](/wiki/Gowron "Gowron") is leader of the [Klingon High Council](/wiki/Klingon_High_Council "Klingon High Council"). O'Reilly also appeared as Gowron in _Deep Space Nine_. O'Reilly appeared in an episode of _Enterprise_ as a different character.
  * [Dwight Schultz](/wiki/Dwight_Schultz "Dwight Schultz") as Lieutenant [Reginald Barclay](/wiki/Reginald_Barclay "Reginald Barclay") is a technician and engineer who also plays a prominent role in the later seasons of _Voyager_.
  * [Patti Yasutake](/wiki/Patti_Yasutake "Patti Yasutake") as Ensign [Alyssa Ogawa](/wiki/Alyssa_Ogawa "Alyssa Ogawa") is a nurse in Dr. Crusher's sickbay.

There were certain big changes for regular characters, the major one was that
Tasha Yar is only in season one, and Wesley left for Starfleet Academy in
Season 4. In Season 2 the doctor is Pulaski not Crusher, but Crusher does come
back and remains the ship's doctor thereafter (In All Good Things it is
revealed she eventually marries Picard and has her own starship command, thus
becoming the new Captain Picard, as he retired to tend a vineyard). In many
cases the characters, or at least the actors, come back to act in some role on
the show. There are many reoccurring characters, some of them have actually
more appearances in episodes than Tasha. (See [List of Star Trek: The Next
Generation cast

## Story arcs &
themes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Story arcs & themes")]

Star Trek had a number of story arcs within the larger story, and oftentimes
different episodes contributed to two or more different story or character
arcs. These could be grouped in different ways, and one way was by the aliens
they were interacting with, for example _TNG_ introduced the Borg and the
Cardassians. The Klingons and Romulans had been introduced in the original
series (1966–69); however, the Klingons were somewhat re-booted with "turtle-
head" look, although a [retcon](/wiki/Retcon "Retcon") was given for this in
an _Enterprise_ episode. Another way to group them is by a certain character
such as Q or Ro Laren or by a technology like the holo-deck, and there were
many other alien encounters (usually funny foreheads, face-paint, or no-body).
Often the plot for alien encounters involved some eccentric alien nature that
caused tensions, revealed at the end

Alien sagas

The Borg:

  * [Q Who](/wiki/Q_Who "Q Who") (May 8, 1989) - introduces Borg also a Q-show
  * [The Best of Both Worlds, Part I & Part II](/wiki/The_Best_of_Both_Worlds_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Best of Both Worlds \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)") (June 18, 1990 & September 24, 1990) - Major Borg diptych 
    * [Family](/wiki/Family_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Family \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)") (October 1, 1990) - Aftermath of BoBW
  * [I, Borg](/wiki/I,_Borg "I, Borg") (May 10, 1992) - Introduces Hue
  * [Descent, Part I & Part II](/wiki/Descent_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Descent \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)") (June 21, 1993 & September 20, 1993) - Another Borg diptych

Certain episodes go deeper into the Klingon alien saga, which are famous for
having an actual [Klingon language](/wiki/Klingon_language "Klingon language")
made for them in the trekiverse. The Klingon stories usually involve Worf, but
not all Worf-centric shows are focused on Klingons. The famous Duras sisters,
a Klingon duo Lursa and B'Etor, were introduced on TNG in 1991 on Redemption
(S5-S5 bridge) and they later appeared in the film Generations

Klingon stories (_examples_) :

  * "[Heart of Glory](/wiki/Heart_of_Glory "Heart of Glory")" (S1E20)
  * "[A Matter of Honor](/wiki/A_Matter_of_Honor "A Matter of Honor") (S2E8) - Riker on a Klingon vessel
  * "[Sins of the Father](/wiki/Sins_of_the_Father_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Sins of the Father \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" (S3E17) (introduces Worf's brother Kurn)
  * "[Redemption](/wiki/Redemption_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Redemption \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" (S4-S5 cliffhanger and bridge, two parts) (Explores Klingon politics and homeworld)
  * "[Birthright](/wiki/Birthright_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Birthright \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" (S6E16 & S6E17, two-part episode)
  * "[Rightful Heir](/wiki/Rightful_Heir "Rightful Heir")" (S6E23) - Introduces Kahless
  * "[Firstborn](/wiki/Firstborn_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Firstborn \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" (TNG S7E21) (Alexander-Worf focused episode)

The Klingon saga established by TNG was significantly continued on the Deep
Space Nine tv show, which continued the Worf character for another 4 seasons

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Reception")]

See also: [List of awards and nominations received by Star Trek: The Next
Generation](/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation
"List of awards and nominations received by Star Trek: The Next Generation")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Enterprise-
D_crew_quarters.jpg/220px-Enterprise-
D_crew_quarters.jpg)](/wiki/File:Enterprise-D_crew_quarters.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Enterprise-D_crew_quarters.jpg "Enlarge")

Exhibit in Los Angeles featuring the crew quarters of Captain Picard (uniform
shown)

_The Next Generation_ 's average of 20 million viewers often exceeded both
existing syndication successes such as _[Wheel of
Fortune](/wiki/Wheel_of_Fortune_\(U.S._game_show\) "Wheel of Fortune \(U.S.
game show\)")_ and network hits including _[Cheers](/wiki/Cheers "Cheers")_
and _[L.A. Law](/wiki/L.A._Law "L.A. Law")_. Benefiting in part from many
stations' decision to air each new episode twice in a week, it consistently
ranked in the top ten among hour-long dramas, and networks could not prevent
affiliates from preempting their shows with _The Next Generation_ or other
dramas that imitated its syndication strategy.[21][17]:124 _Star Trek: The
Next Generation_ received 18 [Emmy Awards](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award") and,
in its seventh season, became the first and only syndicated television show to
be nominated for the Emmy for Best Dramatic Series. It was nominated for three
[Hugo Awards](/wiki/Hugo_Award "Hugo Award") and won two. The first-season
episode "[The Big Goodbye](/wiki/The_Big_Goodbye "The Big Goodbye")" also won
the [Peabody Award](/wiki/Peabody_Award "Peabody Award") for excellence in
television programming.

In 1997, the episode "[The Best of Both Worlds, Part
I](/wiki/The_Best_of_Both_Worlds_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Best
of Both Worlds \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" was ranked No. 70 on [_TV
Guide_ 's 100 Greatest Episodes of All
Time](/wiki/TV_Guide%27s_100_Greatest_Episodes_of_All_Time "TV Guide's 100
Greatest Episodes of All Time").[53] In 2002, _Star Trek: The Next Generation_
was ranked #46 on [_TV Guide_ 's 50 Greatest TV Shows of All
Time](/wiki/TV_Guide%27s_50_Greatest_TV_Shows_of_All_Time "TV Guide's 50
Greatest TV Shows of All Time") list,[54] and in 2008, was ranked No. 37 on
_[Empire](/wiki/Empire_\(magazine\) "Empire \(magazine\)")_ 's list of the 50
greatest television shows.[55]

On October 7, 2006, one of the three original filming models of the USS
_Enterprise_ -D used on the show sold at a [Christie's](/wiki/Christie%27s
"Christie's") auction for USD $576,000, making it the highest-selling item at
the event.[56] The buyer of the piece was [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft
"Microsoft") co-founder [Paul Allen](/wiki/Paul_Allen "Paul Allen"), owner of
the [Museum of Pop Culture](/wiki/Museum_of_Pop_Culture "Museum of Pop
Culture") in Seattle. The piece is on display within the Science Fiction
Museum.

In 2012, _Entertainment Weekly_ listed the show at No. 7 in the "25 Best Cult
TV Shows from the Past 25 Years", saying, "The original _[Star
Trek](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Original_Series "Star Trek: The Original Series")_
was cult TV before cult TV was even a thing, but its younger, sleeker
offspring brought, yes, a new generation into the Trekker fold, and reignited
the promise of sci-fi on television."[57] Although TNG did develop a cult
following, it was noted for its prime-time general audience viewership
also.[5]

The flute from "Inner Light" was valued at only a few hundred to perhaps 1000
USD when it went to auction, but was sold for over 40,000; in this case the
auctioneers admitted they had underestimated the appeal of the
prop.[58][59][59]

In the days leading up to the auction, [Denise Okuda](/wiki/Denise_Okuda
"Denise Okuda"), former _Trek_ scenic artist and video supervisor, as well as
co-writer of the auction catalog, said: "That's the item people say they
really have to have, because it's so iconic to a much-beloved episode."[60]

Episodes with highest Nielsen ratings (Examples)[39]

  * "All Good Things..." (1994), the finale achieved a rating of 17.4[42]
  * "Encounter at Farpoint" (1987), rating of 15.7[61]
  * "Unification" (1991), 15.4, a duology featuring [Leonard Nimoy](/wiki/Leonard_Nimoy "Leonard Nimoy") as Spoc in Part II brought in the highest Nielsen ratingsof that Season, and the one of the highest known for TNG except for the pilot and finale.[39]
  * "Aquiel" (1993), 14.1 [39] (Featured Guest star [Renée Jones](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9e_Jones "Renée Jones") as Aquiel)
  * "A Matter of Time" (1991), 13.9 (Featuring guest star [Matt Frewer](/wiki/Matt_Frewer "Matt Frewer") as a time traveler)
  * "Relics" (1992), 13.9 (This one featured [James Doohan](/wiki/James_Doohan "James Doohan") as Scotty)
  * "Time's Arrow, Part II" (1992), 13.8 (S6 opener and conclusion of the Time's Arrow duology)
  * "Tapestry" (1993), 13.8[39] (Q-show)

DS9's "The Emissary", which came out half-way through season 6 of TNG achieved
a Nielsen rating of 18.8.[62] Star Trek's ratings went into a steady decline
starting with Season 6 of TNG, and the second to last episode of DS9 achieved
a Nielsen rating of 3.9.[63]

## Computer and video

"Edit section: Computer and video games")]

Examples of video games based on _The Next Generation_ TV series, movies, and
characters include:

    * _[Star Trek: The Next Generation: Echoes from the Past](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation:_Echoes_from_the_Past "Star Trek: The Next Generation: Echoes from the Past")_ (1993) _a port of Futures Past for the Sega Genesis_
  * _[Star Trek Generations: Beyond the Nexus](/wiki/Star_Trek_Generations:_Beyond_the_Nexus "Star Trek Generations: Beyond the Nexus")_ (1994), for Nintendo Game Boy or Sega Game Gear
  * _[Star Trek: The Next Generation – A Final Unity](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation_%E2%80%93_A_Final_Unity "Star Trek: The Next Generation – A Final Unity")_ (1995), for MS-DOS or Macintosh 
    * A Final Unity sold 500,000 copies by 1996.[64]
  * [Star Trek: Borg](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Borg "Star Trek: Borg") (1996) (Includes live action segments directed by James L. Conway and acting by John de Lancie as Q)
  * _[Star Trek Generations](/wiki/Star_Trek_Generations_\(video_game\) "Star Trek Generations \(video game\)")_ (1997), for IBM PC
  * _[Star Trek: The Next Generation: Klingon Honor Guard](/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation:_Klingon_Honor_Guard "Star Trek: The Next Generation: Klingon Honor Guard")_ (1998), for Mac and Windows 95 and 98
  * _[Star Trek: Hidden Evil](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Hidden_Evil "Star Trek: Hidden Evil")_ (1999), for Windows 95 and 98
  * _[Star Trek Invasion](/wiki/Star_Trek_Invasion "Star Trek Invasion")_ (2000), for the [PlayStation](/wiki/PlayStation "PlayStation")
  * _[Star Trek Armada](/wiki/Star_Trek_Armada "Star Trek Armada")_ (2000),[65] for [Microsoft Windows 98](/wiki/Microsoft_Windows_98 "Microsoft Windows 98")
  * _[Star Trek: Armada II](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Armada_II "Star Trek: Armada II")_ (2001)
  * _[Star Trek: Bridge Commander](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Bridge_Commander "Star Trek: Bridge Commander")_ (2002)
  * _[Star Trek: Conquest](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Conquest "Star Trek: Conquest")_ (2002) (Wii, PlayStation 2)

The Enterprise and its setting is also in other Trekiverse games like [Star
Trek: Armada](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Armada "Star Trek: Armada") (2000), by which
time it was common to have a game set in the time and place inhabited by TNG,
but also occupied by two more television shows and the films. For example, in
Star Trek: Armada voice actors from The Next Generation contributed to their
characters in the game including [Patrick Stewart](/wiki/Patrick_Stewart
"Patrick Stewart") reprised the roles of Jean-Luc Picard and Locutus, [Michael
Dorn](/wiki/Michael_Dorn "Michael Dorn") voiced Worf, [Denise
Crosby](/wiki/Denise_Crosby "Denise Crosby") reprised
[Sela](/wiki/Sela_\(Star_Trek\) "Sela \(Star Trek\)"), and [J. G.
Hertzler](/wiki/J._G._Hertzler "J. G. Hertzler")[66] voiced Chancellor Martok.
Several other voice actors who had been previously unaffiliated with _Star
Trek_ also voiced characters in the game, among them was Richard Penn.[67]

_Star Trek: Armada II_ was set in the _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ era of
the Star Trek universe.[65]

_[Star Trek: Hidden Evil](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Hidden_Evil "Star Trek: Hidden
Evil")_ , which came out in 1999 not only included voice acting by [Brent
Spiner](/wiki/Brent_Spiner "Brent Spiner") as [Data](/wiki/Data_\(Star_Trek\)
"Data \(Star Trek\)") and [Patrick Stewart](/wiki/Patrick_Stewart "Patrick
Stewart") as Picard,[68] but the story was a follow-on from the ninth _[Star
Trek](/wiki/Star_Trek "Star Trek")_ movie, _[Star Trek:
Insurrection](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Insurrection "Star Trek: Insurrection")_.[68]

## Release
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Release history")]

###
VHS[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: VHS")]

All episodes of _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ were made available on
[VHS](/wiki/VHS "VHS") cassettes, starting in 1991. The entire series was
gradually released on VHS over the next few years during the remainder of the
show's run and after the show had ended.

The [VHS](/wiki/VHS "VHS") for TNG were available on mail-order usually two
episodes per VHS cassette.

###
LaserDisc[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: LaserDisc")]

Paramount published all episodes on the [LaserDisc](/wiki/LaserDisc
"LaserDisc") format from October 1991 using an extended release schedule that
concluded in May 1999. Each disc featured two episodes with Closed Captions,
Digital Audio, and CX encoding. Also published were four themed "collections",
or boxed sets, of related episodes. These included _The Borg Collective_ ,
_The Q Continuum_ , _Worf: Return to Grace_ , and _The Captains
Collection_.[71]

There was a production error with episode 166, "Sub Rosa", where a faulty
master tape was used that was missing 4½ minutes of footage. Though a new
master copy of the episode was obtained, no corrected pressing of this disc
was issued.[71]

_Star Trek: The Next Generation_ was also released on LaserDisc in the non-US
markets Japan and Europe. In Japan, all episodes were released in a series of
14 boxed sets (two boxed sets per season), and as with the US releases were in
the NTSC format and ordered by production code. The European laserdiscs were
released in the PAL format and included the ten two-part telemovies as well as
a disc featuring the episodes _Yesterday 's Enterprise_ and _Cause And
Effect_. The pilot episode, _Encounter At Farpoint_ , was also included in a
boxed set called _Star Trek: The Pilots_ featuring the pilot episodes from
_Star Trek: The Original Series_ , _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ , _Star
Trek: Deep Space Nine_ , and _Star Trek: Voyager_.

###
DVD[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: DVD")]

The first season of the series was released on [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") in March
2002. Throughout the year the next six seasons were released at various times
on DVD, with the seventh season being released in December 2002. To
commemorate the 20th anniversary of the series, [CBS Home
Entertainment](/wiki/CBS_Home_Entertainment "CBS Home Entertainment") and
Paramount Home Entertainment released _Star Trek: The Next Generation – The
Complete Series_ on October 2, 2007. The DVD box set contains 49 discs.
Between March 2006 and September 2008, "Fan Collective" editions were released
containing select episodes of _The Next Generation_ (and _The Original Series_
, _Deep Space Nine_ , and _Voyager_) based on various themes. The individual
episodes were chosen by fans voting on [StarTrek.com](/wiki/StarTrek.com
"StarTrek.com"). In total, six "Fan Collectives" were produced, along with a
boxed set containing the first five collectives. In April 2013 all seven
seasons of _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ were re-released in new packaging
featuring a silhouette of a different cast member on each box. However, the
discs contained the identical content that was previously released in 2002.

### Blu-
ray[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Blu-ray")]

The original show was shot on high-quality [35 mm film](/wiki/35_mm_film "35
mm film"), but had to be downscaled before editing and postprocessing to
standard '80s and '90s TV resolution (video quality) for broadcast. The show's
final visual effects (e.g. all exterior shots of the starship _Enterprise_ ,
phaser fire or beaming fade-ins and -outs) were also composed only in standard
resolution video. All previous home video and DVD releases used this severely
downscaled version. To include such footage on [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-
ray"), using only [upscaling](/wiki/Image_scaling "Image scaling"), would have
resulted in a larger but blurred image, so CBS decided to use a more detailed
approach to bring the show to high definition. They also opted to adhere to
the show's original 4:3 aspect ratio.

A news release on the official website announced on September 28, 2011, in
celebration of the series' twenty-fifth anniversary, that _Star Trek: The Next
Generation_ would be completely re-mastered in 1080p and 4k high definition
from the original 35 mm film [negatives](/wiki/Negative_\(photography\)
"Negative \(photography\)") (consisting of almost 25,000 reels of original
film stock). All the visual effects for each episode would be digitally
recomposed from original large-format negatives and newly created CGI shots.
The release would be accompanied by 7.1 [DTS](/wiki/DTS_\(sound_system\) "DTS
\(sound system\)") Master Audio.

An initial disc featuring the episodes "Encounter at Farpoint", "[Sins of the
Father](/wiki/Sins_of_the_Father_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "Sins of
the Father \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", and "[The Inner
Light](/wiki/The_Inner_Light_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Inner
Light \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" was released on January 31, 2012
under the label "The Next Level". The six-disc first season set was released
on July 24, 2012.[72] The remaining seasons were released periodically
thereafter, culminating in the release of the seventh season on December 2,
2014.

The entire re-mastered series is available on Blu-ray as individual seasons,
and as a 41-disc box set titled _The Full Journey_. Eventually, all remastered
episodes will also be available for television syndication and digital
distribution.[73] [Mike Okuda](/wiki/Mike_Okuda "Mike Okuda") believes this is
the largest film restoration project ever attempted.[74]

Season | Release date[75] | Special features  
---|---|---  
Season One | July 24, 2012 | Documentaries "Energized!" (about the VFX remastering) and "Stardate Revisited" (Origin)  
Season Two | December 4, 2012 | Extended version of "[The Measure of a Man](/wiki/The_Measure_of_a_Man_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Measure of a Man \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")", Reunification: reunion interview with entire _TNG_ cast.  
Season Three | April 30, 2013 | Inside the Writer's Room, Resistance is Futile: Assimilating _TNG_ , A Tribute to Michael Piller  
Season Four | July 30, 2013 | In Conversation: The _Star Trek_ Art Department, Relativity: The Family Saga of _Star Trek TNG_ , Deleted scenes  
Season Five | November 19, 2013 | In Conversation: The Music of _TNG_ , Requiem: A Remembrance of _TNG_ , Deleted scenes  
Season Six | June 24, 2014 | Beyond the Five Year Mission- The Evolution of _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ , Deleted scenes  
Season Seven | December 2, 2014 | The Sky's the Limit – The Eclipse of _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ , In Conversation: Lensing _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ , deleted scenes

#### The Measure of a Man HD extended
cut[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: The Measure of a Man HD extended cut")]

Main article: [The Measure of a Man (Star Trek: The Next
Generation)](/wiki/The_Measure_of_a_Man_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\)
"The Measure of a Man \(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")

A famous episode, "The Measure of a Man ", which broke-out of entertainment
into academia was released in HD in 2012 with an extended cut.[77] The
extended version includes an extra 13 minutes of footage as well as recreated
special effects.[78] It was released as part of the Season 2 collection set.

Star Trek: The Next Generation spawned a lot of media set in its science-
fiction vision, which was primarily the 2370s but set in the same universe as
first Star Trek TV shows of the 1960s. This included the aforementioned films,
computer games, board games, theme parks etc. In the 2010s there was still
discussion about a Captain Worf spin-off, the Bridge officer that debuted on
TNG and was also featured in the TNG spin-off show Deep Space Nine, which
itself had quite a following.[79]

### These Are The Voyages...
(2005)[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: These Are The Voyages... \(2005\)")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Jonathan_Frakes_cropped1.jpg/200px-
Jonathan_Frakes_cropped1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jonathan_Frakes_cropped1.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Marina_Sirtis_at_Deepcon_10.jpg/108px-
Marina_Sirtis_at_Deepcon_10.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marina_Sirtis_at_Deepcon_10.jpg)

Jonathan Frakes and Marina Sirtis returned to their _The Next Generation_
roles for the series finale of _Enterprise_.

In 2005, the last episode of "Enteprise" called "[These Are the
Voyages...](/wiki/These_Are_the_Voyages... "These Are the Voyages...")"
(S4E22) featured a [holodeck](/wiki/Holodeck "Holodeck") simulation on the
[USS _Enterprise_ (NCC-1701-D)](/wiki/USS_Enterprise_\(NCC-1701-D\) "USS
Enterprise \(NCC-1701-D\)") from _Star Trek: The Next Generation_ during the
events of the episode "[The
Pegasus](/wiki/The_Pegasus_\(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation\) "The Pegasus
\(Star Trek: The Next Generation\)")" and the return of Commander [William
Riker](/wiki/William_Riker "William Riker") ([Jonathan
Frakes](/wiki/Jonathan_Frakes "Jonathan Frakes")) and Counselor [Deanna
Troi](/wiki/Deanna_Troi "Deanna Troi") ([Marina Sirtis](/wiki/Marina_Sirtis
"Marina Sirtis")).[80] It was written by Berman and Braga, who noted "... this
was a very cool episode because it has a great concept driving it".[81]

[Star Trek: Enterprise](/wiki/Star_Trek:_Enterprise "Star Trek: Enterprise")
was TV show launched following Star Trek: Voyager conclusion, and was set 100
years before TOS and 200 years before TNG, in addition to including some soft
re-boot elements with an all new cast. Some episodes connected to TNG directly
including guest stars by Brent Spiner and connections to the events in TNG's
fictional universe. The three-episode [story arc](/wiki/Story_arc "Story arc")
consisting of "[Borderland](/wiki/Borderland_\(Star_Trek:_Enterprise\)
"Borderland \(Star Trek: Enterprise\)")", "[Cold Station
12](/wiki/Cold_Station_12 "Cold Station 12")", and "[The
Augments](/wiki/The_Augments "The Augments")", with a Soong ancestor portrayed
by _The Next Generation_ regular [Brent Spiner](/wiki/Brent_Spiner "Brent
Spiner") provides some backstory to Data's back-story. Also [Affliction (Star
Trek: Enterprise)](/wiki/Affliction_\(Star_Trek:_Enterprise\) "Affliction
\(Star Trek: Enterprise\)") also helps explain the smooth-headed Klingons that
sometimes appeared, a theatrically presented [retcon](/wiki/Retcon "Retcon")
and backstory that helped explain this varying presentation between TOS, TNG,
and Films

Star Trek would not return to television as a show for over 12 years, until
the debut of _Star Trek:Discovery_ on CBS, but thereafter exclusively
available on the internet service [CBS All Access](/wiki/CBS_All_Access "CBS
All Access") (Neflix Internationally) at that time. The film franchise was
rebooted under the Kelvin timeline was quite successful, with several
blockbusters from 2009 and featuring scenes with Spock
